To achieve a full-screen navigation drawer without using any third-party libraries, you can modify your existing code as follows:

1. Remove the action bar from the navigation drawer layout XML file (e.g., activity_main.xml) by removing the `android:theme` attribute or setting it to a theme without an action bar.

2. Modify the `setupMenu` method to include the following code after setting the adapter for the menu ListView:

```java
// Get the root view of the activity
View rootView = getWindow().getDecorView().findViewById(android.R.id.content);

// Set the width of the drawer to match the width of the root view
DrawerLayout.LayoutParams params = (DrawerLayout.LayoutParams) menu.getLayoutParams();
params.width = rootView.getWidth();
menu.setLayoutParams(params);
```

3. Modify the `onDrawerClosed` method inside the `DrawerLayout.SimpleDrawerListener` to include the following code:

```java
// Hide the navigation drawer by sliding it off the screen
drawer.closeDrawer(GravityCompat.START);

// Show the action bar
getSupportActionBar().show();
```

4. Modify the `onDrawerOpened` method inside the `DrawerLayout.SimpleDrawerListener` to include the following code:

```java
// Hide the action bar
getSupportActionBar().hide();
```

<<<explanation>>>: 
This code modifies the existing setupMenu method to set the width of the drawer to match the width of the root view, which effectively makes the navigation drawer full-screen. Additionally, it hides the action bar when the drawer is opened and shows it when the drawer is closed. By using the Activity.findViewById API, we can access the root view of the activity to set the width of the drawer.
